node.statement: CONVENTION AND INEQUALITY: The superadditivity inequality states 1/Phi_n(r) >= 1/Phi_n(p) + 1/Phi_n(q). For n=1, all three Phi values are 0. Under the standard convention 1/0 = +infinity in the extended reals [0,+infinity], this becomes +infinity >= +infinity + +infinity. In the extended reals, +infinity + +infinity = +infinity, and +infinity >= +infinity holds. Alternatively, the harmonic-mean form Phi_n(r) <= Phi_n(p)*Phi_n(q)/(Phi_n(p)+Phi_n(q)) becomes 0 <= 0*0/(0+0) = 0/0. Under the convention that 0/0 = 0 (or that the bound is vacuous when both sides are 0), this also holds. The most natural reading: since Phi_1 is identically 0, the reciprocal 1/Phi_1 is identically +infinity, and the inequality holds trivially in the extended reals. QED for n=1.
